feed.title: Trivial QC signatures with clean upgrade path

entry.title: Trivial QC signatures with clean upgrade path
entry.summary:
In a recent exchange on the Bitcoin Development Mailing List, an innovative idea was proposed that could enhance Bitcoin's security in the face of quantum computing threats. The discussion began with a suggestion to combine a new concept with a previous idea for creating a Non-Uniform Memory Access (NUMS) or trust-minimized public key that is compatible with Bitcoin. This proposed public key would have a security strength of less than 128 bits, specifically around 96 bits. The rationale behind this is to provide a solution that could preemptively address the vulnerabilities posed by quantum computing before it becomes capable of breaking the current encryption standards used in Bitcoin.
The motivation for this proposal stems from the anticipation of quantum computing advancements, which are expected to eventually make traditional cryptographic keys insecure. By introducing a public key with deliberately reduced security strength, it becomes possible to set up a sort of bounty system. This system would allow for the key to be claimed—demonstrating the potential breach—months or even years before quantum computers reach the capability to compromise regular Bitcoin keys. This approach aims not just to test the resilience of Bitcoin against quantum attacks but also to act as an early warning system, giving the community time to react and upgrade security measures before any actual vulnerabilities can be exploited by operators of quantum computers.
This conversation underscores the proactive steps being taken within the Bitcoin development community to safeguard the cryptocurrency against future technological advancements. It reflects a strategic approach to security, where potential threats are addressed long before they materialize, ensuring that Bitcoin remains secure and trustworthy for its users. Such discussions are vital for the ongoing evolution and adaptation of Bitcoin's underlying technology to meet emerging challenges head-on.
